results.title: Aardman classics
results.creator_credit: David Sproxton, Nick Park, Peter Lord, Steve Box and Aardman Animations
results.brief_description: Compilation of early Aardman short works, ranging from 1978-1999. Aardman, the animation studio specialising in claymation, are renowned for their humour, especially in relation to the portrayal of animals. Highlights here include “Pib and Pog” and “My baby just cares for me”.

results.title: A.I. Artificial intelligence
results.creator_credit: Steven Spielberg, Bonnie Curtis, Kathleen Kennedy, NBCUniversal and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: A.I. is the story of David, a cyber boy, realistically designed and programmed to provide unconditional love to its owner. He enters the home of Monica and David, where Monica, after initial problems, embraces his presence… until their biological son returns.

constellations_other.name: 9.5mm Pathe-Baby and parents behaving badly
constellations_other.description: A look at the link between the Pathé-Baby system and animation, as well as the relationship between cinematic parents and their children.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Steven Spielberg, Bonnie Curtis, Kathleen Kennedy, NBCUniversal and Warner Bros Pictures
results.description: Intending “A.I.” as a collaboration between himself and Steven Spielberg, Stanley Kubrick created various treatments and hundreds of storyboards for the film - upon Kubrick’s death Spielberg inherited the project as director and co-producer. “A.I.” is the story of David, a cyber boy, realistically designed and programmed to provide unconditional love to its owner. David enters the home of Monica and David, where Monica, after initial problems, embraces his presence. Trouble brews however when Martin (the couple’s biological son, recovering from an illness) returns home and displaces David. David is turned out into the wilderness where he meets Gigolo Joe, a love robot on the run. Joe and David visit Rouge City, in search of the Blue Fairy (whom David is convinced will grant him mortality) and then to a Flesh Fair where the two witness a carnival of robot torture. “A.I.” is a fantastical quest that depicts a robot yearning to be real and hence loved, themes echoed in “Pinocchio” (a touchstone in the film) and “Blade runner.” A film with three quite distinct acts, “A.I.” is saturated with memorable images, set pieces and costumes, as well as some interesting concepts and ethical moral dilemmas but is compromised by its eagerness to provide David with a happy ending.

results.title: A Zoo in the trees
results.creator_credit: Louise Jonas, Rob McCubbin and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre
results.brief_description: The trees which protect us are in imminent danger. If we don’t speak now in defence of our remaining forests, we betray our own future. Judith Wright This program deals with the importance of forest preservation in all parts of the world as they are the life support systems for tree dwelling animals. By saving the trees we are also savings the various species which inhabit them. Groups of monkeys, apes and primitive lemurs at the Royal Melbourne Zoo are intimately observed feeding, caring for their young, grooming and communicating with each other. These primates are contrasted with Australia’s tree dwelling animals, the koala, lace monitor, the grey-headed fruit bat and the green tree frog. Photographed by Frank Few and Rob McCubbin, narrated by Desley Blanch and featuring music composed and performed by Don Burrowes and aboriginal music by the Bwung-Gul Aboriginal Culture Group. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: A Year in Provence
results.creator_credit: David Tucker, Ken Riddington and BBC
results.brief_description: Based on Peter Mayles’ best selling novel, Peter and his wife Annie decide to take “Le Plunge” and abandon the rat-race of England to live in an old farmhouse at the foot of the Luberon Mountains in Provence. Coping with the language and the idiosyncratic behaviour and customs of the locals form the basis of their daily life.

results.title: Above the dust level [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Carla Drago, Kath Shelper, Australian Film Commission and Scarlett Pictures
results.brief_description: Set against a Sydney backdrop, a hypochondriac, her junkie ex-lover and a neighbour with a life threatening illness are united by dust, allergies and disappearing grey Y-fronts. Cast includes Jane Turner, Tobin Saunders and Melinda Dimitriades. (Awards: Winner of numerous awards, including Best Australian Short Comedy Award, MIFF 1999; Highly Commended, Melbourne Queer Film and Video Festival, 2000; Bronze Award, Houston Film Festival, 2000)

results.title: Ablett: one special season
results.creator_credit: Dean Shiel, Stephen Phillips and Australian Football Video
results.brief_description: In one special season Gary Ablett redefined the way Australian Rules football’s rich history will judge him. Having set standards rarely matched by other players since his career began, Ablett’s 1993 was quite extraordinary - even for a man prone to producing the extraordinary. We follow Ablett’s path through the season, hear him speak on his performance and his place in the Geelong team and travel to Nauru with him as he umpires the local Grand Final. This is a fine tribute to one of the legends of the game.

results.title: ABC for kids: bumper collection
results.brief_description: A collection of children’s classic television for the very young to enjoy. “Invisible Bananas” and “Teddy chase”, the lovable Bananas In Pyjamas have fun with the teddies in these two episodes. “Postman Pat and the suit of armour”, Postman Pat helps get Garner Hall ready to be open to the public. “The Kite”, Brum the little car helps to rescue a runaway kite. “Where’s Spot?” and “Spot follows his nose”, little Spot the dog hides from his mum and looks for something that smells nice in these two episodes. “Thomas comes to breakfast” and “Four Little Engines”, Thomas the Tank Engine and Friends get up to mischief in these two episodes. “Hey hey Blinky Bill”, “Whistle Song” and “Earthquake”, two songs with Blinky Bill followed by an episode about his gang getting stuck in an old mine. “Pingu as chef” and “Pingu as baby sitter”, enjoy Pingu the penguin’s adventures as he pops popcorn and then looks after twin babies in these two episodes. “Party at Owl’s House”, join in the party with Little Bear and his friends as they have a “because” party.

results.title: ABC
results.brief_description: Visually suggests the origins of the English alphabet from the signs and symbols used by the Egyptians, Semitic, Phoenoecian, Greek, Roman and Medieval people. Could be used in a wide variety of applications including studies of signs and symbols, graphic communications, art, language arts.

results.title: Abba gold: greatest hits
results.brief_description: Abba’s enduring musical heritage has remained vibrant despite the band’s breakup in the 1980’s. Their success has been revitalised by copy bands, motion picture soundtracks and cover versions of their songs. This compilation tape presents video-clips of Abba’s most popular hits capturing the music, fashion and dance steps universally associated with the band. The songs featured on this tape are: 1. Dancing queen 2. Knowing me, knowing you 3. Take a chance on me 4. Mamma mia 5. Lay all your love on me 6. Super trouper 7. The Winner takes it all 8. Money, money, money 9. S.O.S. 10. Chiquitita 11. Fernando 12. Voulez vous 13. Gimme! Gimme! Gimme! (a man after midnight) 14. Does your mother know 15. One of us 16. I have a dream 17. The Name of the game 18. Thank you for the music 19. Waterloo.

results.title: Aardman animations. Vol. 01
results.creator_credit: Barry Purves, David Sproxton, Nick Park, Peter Lord, Richard Goleszowski, Stephen Johnson and Aardman Animations
results.brief_description: David Sproxton and Peter Lord began making films together at school, and in 1972 set up Aardman Animations in Bristol, specialising in model animation and claymation. This selection from the studio includes “Barefootin’”, an early pop-promo with a track by Robert Parker; “Next”, a witty 5 minute condensation of the entire Shakespearean theatrical canon; “Late Edition”, a warts-and-all look at a “right-on” newspaper; “My Baby Just Cares for Me”, a feline interpretation of the Nina Simone song; “Sledgehammer”, the celebrated Peter Gabriel clip; and the 1991 Academy Award winning interviews-at-the-zoo, “Creature Comforts” plus its highly successful follow-on, the Heat Electric TV commercials.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Barry Purves, David Sproxton, Nick Park, Peter Lord, Richard Goleszowski, Stephen Johnson and Aardman Animations
